utterance.speaker: Originally aired
utterance.content: Sept 19 2006

utterance.speaker: Doctor
utterance.content: You're not gonna make this easy, are you? Unfortunately; as much as I admire your spirit, je ne sais rien.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 71 year old cancer research specialist. Minor tremors, localized melanoma removed 2 years ago, cataracts. And he can't breathe. Also, disregard the facial lacerations. They're creepy, but unfortunately irrelevant. Don't you wanna know why?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You… have your cane.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, why the lacerations are creepy. He was about to dissect one of his lab rats when he collapsed. The little vermin seized the day, so to speak and went medieval on his ass. What, my fly open?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So the… the pain's returned.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There was no pain, he was unconscious. I'm guessing, because he wasn't able to breathe.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We're talking about you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Obviously. I'm obviously not. What is it with you people? I don't use the cane, you're shocked. I use the cane…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We're just concerned.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: About the wrong person. I can breathe. Ezra Powell on the other hand, is gonna die.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: THE Ezra Powell???

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The researcher? The guy who wrote that textbook?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: *That* textbook, THE textbook.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Wait - there's actually another doctor you admire?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I… admire lots of doctors. 'Course most of them look a lot better in knee socks than Ezra Powell, but seeing as they can all breathe.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Oxygenation is through the floor and lungs are full of fluid. Gotta be his heart; could be amyloidosis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or his lungs; probably from using and inhaling toxic chemicals in his lab.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It's not the lungs. Chest x-ray is clean.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So's his EKG, it's not his heart.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're being too nice. Outside the hospital he can't breathe, inside the hospital he can. Means we help, at least enough to screw with our test results. The source of the problem's either in his heart or his lungs. So all we gotta do is stop helping, put a little pressure on him, and see which gives out first.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: At 71, we get his heart or lungs to give out we might not get 'em to give in again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's why we're gonna do it in a hospital. Put him on an incline treadmill and do a stress EKG.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So much for the admiration.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Let's get you started. I'll turn your oxygen up.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: I… I worked with Williams on the first protocol for this machine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Everyone still uses it.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: Except for Williams. He died four years ago.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: He was 84. He died parasailing. He was always an idiot.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You okay? Hang in there. You know the protocol’s only a few minutes.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His heart rate's flat. We don’t get it past 130, we're not gonna see anything.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And if he falls and breaks a hip, we're not gonna see anything

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I figured House might go back to the pills, but if he's using his cane he's right back to where he was before. Maybe even worse.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Luckily he'll handle it in a stoic, grown-up fashion -- he'd never take it out on us.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: I can't. I… I gotta stop.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Just a little longer.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His heartbeat's only 90. I'm gonna increase the incline.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: I gotta stop. I… I… I gotta get off.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You're doing great, just a little faster, okay?

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: I don't need a cheerleader, I need oxygen.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Stop, this isn't working.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His heart rate barely got above 90.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He can't breathe, there's too much fluid in his lungs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: REALLY!? He's got FLUID in his lungs, whatever are we gonna do?? Oh yeah, now I remember. Put him on a treadmill and run him like one of his rats on a wheel.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He can't run, he can hardly walk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's 'cause he's not trying hard enough. If he was, his heart rate would go up.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Exercising with a lung full of your own bodily fluids tends to hurt.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They don't call it a stress test for nothing. Do it again.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He's drowning!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then pull him outta the pool, and… Do. It. Again.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: I'm assuming this isn't your idea of a long term solution.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We need to get rid of the fluid in your lungs, so you'll be able to do the test.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: To see if it's my heart, or my lungs.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Exactly.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: My money's on both. I've been in and out of the hospital for the past year. I'm old. And sick. I'm getting older and sicker. Not a very interesting differential, but… Oh!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I'm in.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: You don't need a $400 handbag.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's kinda hard to check your throat when you're flapping your gums around.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Oh… sorry.

utterance.speaker: Daughter
utterance.content: But it's for the fall formal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He doesn't care if it's for the presidential inauguration.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Uh huh.

utterance.speaker: Daughter
utterance.content: But I'm using Marissa's old dress, it's free.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, you know what else is free? The roof over your head, the food you eat, your phone, your computer. How long have you been congested?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: All week, ever since we got back from Fresno.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fresno. That's in France, right? See the Parthenon?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Uh, California. I've got no appetite, I'm aching all over, I'm weak...

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does that hurt?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does his voice always have that unattractive nasal tone?

utterance.speaker: Daughter
utterance.content: Totally.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm gonna take that giggle as a no. Fever, aches, weakness, loss of appetite. You been having any anal sex with I.V. drug users lately?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Of course not, I'm married.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think she might've been having--

utterance.speaker: Dad and Daughter
utterance.content: NO!!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's probably a rhinovirus.

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: What's that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cold. Take this 4 times a day, and stay off airplanes. Flying cesspools.

utterance.speaker: Daughter
utterance.content: Oops! You dropped something. If there's anything else you can think of, please call.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He's… too old and weak.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: Yeah, this is way better. This'll work.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Just try.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There are 20 words to describe chest pain -- burning, squeezing, stabbing, tearing -- each one diagnostically useful. For that you have to thank Dr. Powell's textbook. There are no words to describe degrees of what he's feeling right now -- shortness of breath. If he'd worked on those issues, there would be. Because he never would have given up until he had an answer.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: This isn't working.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: Dr. House…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Please don't get up. I'm sure you're very busy. I'm just gonna try and speed things up a little.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Is that Epi? That's not the protocol.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, the protocol, is what you tried to do and failed each time. Over 100… now we're getting somewhere. How's it look, Foreman?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No EKG changes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then we push harder.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House, you're gonna kill him.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: No, he's right, let him -- let him do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See? That's why he doesn't have to wear knee socks.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He can't breathe.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 130. The magic number. Nothing here. Foreman?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Still no sign of blockage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which means it's not the heart. So it must be the lungs. See? That wasn't so hard, was it?

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: No! Just -- give me the rest of the epinephrine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The test is over, it's okay, we're gonna stabilize you.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: No! No. Just let me die.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You're not gonna die.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: Yes, I a-am.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We'll find a treatment.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: I don't wanna live like this. Please. I'm begging you. Kill me.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He says no more tests. He wants to die, and he wants us to help him do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And I want to play a little game I like to call ‘Block My Spike’ with Misty Mae.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He's thought this through; it's not an impulsive decision.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Neither is mine. He's depressed. He'll feel much better after we cure him.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He's seen all the tests we've seen. Even if we figure out what was causing the lung damage, it's too late to reverse it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You can't know that without knowing what's wrong.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It's his call.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So what do we do? We put a plastic bag over his head and get it over with?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No. We give him a syringe full of morphine. Every doctor I've ever practiced with has done it. They don't want to, they don't like to, but that's the way it is.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I haven't, I won't.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I couldn't do it either.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You just said we should respect his decision.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Respect it doesn't necessarily mean we honor it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Right. Just means we talk about it. At some point, do no harm has to mean allowing nature to take its course, not stubbornly standing in the way of it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sticking a metal syringe into a plastic I.V. line and pumping in a lethal dose of morphine is not letting nature take its course. Not according to the state of New Jersey.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So it's better we allow him to slowly suffocate in his own plasma?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Whose side are you on, senator? First respect his wishes, then invade Iraq, then get the troops home. Make up your mind.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow. Certainly a lot of interesting things to consider. Stress EKG rules out the heart, which means something's gotta be attacking his lungs. Mycoplasmas or strep pneumo, which probably means it's too late to do anything about it. We could try levofloxacin.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Coming up with a new treatment isn't gonna do us any good unless we convince him it's worth trying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, come on. He's old, and sick, and tiny. We can do whatever we want to him.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: I don't know. Must've fallen out of bed and got the nasal canula wrapped around his neck somehow.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Ezra, what are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: I don't wanna live hooked to machines, too weak to wipe my own ass.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why would you wanna wipe your own ass when you can have someone do it for you?

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: You're wasting your time. There must be other patients you could actually help.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, all services rendered on a first-come, first-served basis.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: I won't consent! To any more tests. And if anyone tries to so much as touch me, I'll press charges for assault.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay well you heard the man; he wants everyone to leave him alone. Why don't you go first. GET OUT! You came to me, I didn't come to you.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: I figured you'd have the guts to do what had to be done, if it came to that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We're nowhere near that. It's time to test your lungs. Breathe! You have to exhale sometime.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Stop!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House, you're hurting him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're hurting me. Fine; you don't help us, we don't help you. Your lungs slowly fill with fluid. You gasp to catch every breath but never can. Every breath is petrifying. It'll be slow, painful; torturous.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: We don't choose our birth, and we don't choose our death.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What if you could? How 'bout we make a deal? Give me one more day. If I don't find out exactly what's wrong with you by then, I help you die.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 24 hours. Come on, it's not gonna kill you.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: Ha.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Old guy. Lungs. Fluid. Go.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You canNOT help him kill himself.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course I can. Chase says we do it all the time.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Cuddy's not gonna let you…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Enough! You don't want me to kill him. Fine. Here's a big shock; I don't wanna kill him either. How do I not kill him? By you guys doing your job. We have 24 hours to figure out what's wrong with him. Tick tock, tick tock.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I'll draw cultures. Pneumonia; should be bacteria in his blood.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's gonna take longer than 24 hours.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not if I spin down the sample. Separate off the buffy coat, then gram stain for bacteria.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great. Do an amylase, D-dimer, C-reactive peptide, get a urine, and do a bronchial sputum while you're at it. You check his home and lab for radiation and toxins. And do a bone marrow biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: All of that in 24 hours?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nah. Whatever you don't get done you can finish at the autopsy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow. You guys look like crap. Whaddya got?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Purple dye on my fingers.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What'd the bone marrow biopsy show?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Don't have the results.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What? What've you been doing all night?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: JELLO shots and wild sex, what else?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No bacteria in the blood cultures. We still have some cooking, but so far, nothing.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Nothing in the urine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Lab was clean enough to do surgery in, because well, they *do*. There was no sign of viruses or fleas on any of the rats.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. -- Who? – Well… tell her to call the clinic. Then tell her to leave a message, and I'll get back to her. Then tell her to leave a personal message.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Who's that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your protégé. What are these?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dictation tapes. He records everything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Because he's a diligent researcher?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or he's losing his memory.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: A lot of people dictate their notes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, we could assume that, and we'd have nothing. Or we could assume it's a symptom, in which case whatever's in his lungs, is also in his brain. Unless you got something more promising.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I'll go get an MRI of his head.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Keep testing 'til you find something. I'm going to my office to rest for awhile.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: It's been a long time since I took an anatomy class, but I'm pretty sure you're moving farther and farther away from my lungs. Running out of places to look aren't you?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Doesn't mean we're gonna stop looking.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: No, not for six more hours.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You want us to fail?

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: No, but you will.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No abnormal nuclei means no leukemia; he a drinker?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not according to the history.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Which means yes, he drinks, which gives us a nice mundane explanation for the acellularity.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or he's telling the truth. Which means fungus is still on the table.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: But your entire view of human nature gets destroyed. Six of one, half a dozen of the other.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bad news fast. Good news you can take your time.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Head is clean. You were wrong, his faculties are intact.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Too bad. If his brain was addled, we wouldn't have to listen to anything he says.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hand me the 10% KOH.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It's 4 o'clock; we have nothing to tell him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then we have no reason to talk to him. We still haven't ruled out fungus.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yup, we have. No buds, no hyphae.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay. Next procedure; we sneak in, turn back the clock.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: Whole team. Must be bad news.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. Bone marrow biopsy revealed multiple myeloma. It's not good news, but there are some treatments. We have to draw some blood…

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: What about my breathing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Associated hyperviscosity syndrome; gummed up the blood vessels in your lungs.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: Dr. Chase said my calcium is normal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mm. We call him Dr. Idiot.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: There's no M-protein in my urine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Odd presentation.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: So odd that Dr. Cameron doesn't believe it either.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just give me 12 more hours.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: We had a deal. No more tests.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fair enough. Give me six more hours. Listen; there is no evidence that you are terminal.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: You a man of your word or not?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, as a matter of fact, I'm not.

utterance.speaker: Powell
utterance.content: Fine. Then discharge me. My lungs will slowly fill with fluid, I'll gasp to catch every breath, but never can.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Where you going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nowhere.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Everybody who can walk should get outta here.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You can’t do that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can’t do what? Administer a prescription painkiller to a patient who’s in pain? Go. Make sure somebody sees you downstairs in the cafeteria.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I can’t let you do this.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: Either I die in pain or I just die; that’s what the argument is here.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No it’s about whether you die or we murder you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What’s gonna happen here is that someone’s getting a butt-load of morphine. I’m not sure exactly who at this point.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I can’t be a part of this.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: Thank you. I’ve always wondered exactly what was on the other side.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Getting a laryngoscope. Don’t just stand there, help.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: But you told him –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. A little something I like to call a lie. Bad I know, but it’s way further down the list than murder. He’s unconscious. No more whining. I’m gonna keep testing him. Go get a ventilator, not gonna do this all night.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And a reasonable person would obviously consent to being put in a coma against their will just to satisfy your curiosity.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I try to kill him, you’re mad. I don’t kill him you’re mad.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: All he wanted was some dignity.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Were you in that room with him? Was he wearing a tux while he was choking on his own plasma? Keep doing the tests. Take your time, do it right. Go. Get to work. Wait! Cameron, why’d you do these cuts so far down on this MRI of his head?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I wanted to get his brain-stem and his C-spine, make sure his diaphragm wasn’t paralyzed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You also caught the top of his lungs. There’s scarring. You do know that you can’t really pierce me with your stares.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Lung scarring along with the bad bone marrow points to an autoimmune disease. Could be pulmonary fibrosis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or Lupus.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He can kill himself after we get him better. Start him on an IVIG for the Lupus, and get a colonoscopy. Lupus could be hiding there.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I can’t do this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Drama queen.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ascending colon’s clean.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Moving into the sigmoid.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sure could use a little more help around here.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s doing what she believes in.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah. If she was acting on principle, she’d be in here trying to stop us. All she’s doing is running away from the principle so she won’t have to feel uncomfortable facing it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And if you were acting on principle, you would have called the cops when you thought House was killing the guy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Better hurry up.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don’t think she’s gonna have a problem deciding what to tell Cuddy. O2 sats 89 and dropping.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thought you were only supposed to put on a pound a week during your last trimester.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m not pregnant. I heard about your little stunt with Dr. Powell.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not really a stunt. More of a trick, a ruse, a hoodwink.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: A lie.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ok. Lying is sometimes good, right? Like when you’re trying to teach someone a lesson about humility, or something. All I’m trying to do is save his life. He’s not gonna learn anything; I just thought the same principle might apply.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It does.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I coulda just let him die.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Not gonna get sued for keeping him alive.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, we could; we completely disregarded his wishes.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Do you want me to disagree with you? Want me to yell at you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It is comforting.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We’re doctors: We treat patients, we don’t kill them.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How right you are, Dr. Cuddy! We also don’t pad our bills, swipe samples from the pharmacy, or fantasize about the teenage daughters of our patients, either.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: True, better be true, and you’re a pig.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m sorry about your leg.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. We really should spend some time talking about that.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The IVIG made him worse. O2 stats plummeted.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So we know it’s not Lupus. What else could it be?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gonna need an open lung biopsy to confirm.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So, now we’re going to operate on the guy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless you’ve invented a new way of doing an open lung biopsy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When you searched Dr. Powell’s office, did you find a copy of the January, 1967 Massachusetts Medical Journal?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I just figured, if you’re not doing any work, you might like something to pass the time. Centerfold’s a killer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How’s your leg?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It hurts. It’s gonna keep on hurting. You gonna keep on asking?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How’s Ezra Powell?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Resting comfortably.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hmm, that’s not what Cameron says.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I hate practicing medicine in high school.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He’s not asking you to help him kill himself; he’s just asking for help. The disease will kill him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know what he was asking for; I just said ‘no’.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’ve done it before. Plenty of times.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To patients that I knew were terminal.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, give me a break. This has nothing to do with saving a life; you just can’t bear the thought of a patient dying before you’ve been able to figure out why.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If we’re gonna keep refusing to cure patients just to rein in my ego then we might start having a little problem with patient recruitment.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Worried about meeting your one patient a week quota?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m a cripple, remember. Accommodations must be made.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why’d you have me look up that article?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Didn’t you find it interesting?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He injected newborn babies with radioactive agents just to see if they had urethral reflux.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He was curious.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He didn’t even tell their parents he was doing an experiment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He wasn’t doing anything his peers weren’t doing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: His peers at Tuskegee and Willowbrook?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He ignored the rights of the few to save many.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So you’re okay with what he did.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Doesn’t matter what I think. It’s what you think that’s relevant.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Because, if I think less of him, I’ll help you more? You’re wrong. The fact that a patient did bad things doesn’t change anything. He still deserves to have some control over his own body.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If he had control of his own body, he’d be dead.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Some control. We can withhold treatment without killing him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No you can’t! You either help him live, or you help him die; you can’t have it both ways.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well I guess it’s not IPF.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, maybe he’ll die right now. Make everything easy for all of us.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Heart rate’s fast.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: BP’s low.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No breath sounds on the right side; he’s dropped his right lung. Air’s building up in his chest, compressing his heart.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Heart rate’s decreasing.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: BP’s stabilizing.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Withdraws from pain stimuli on the left side, but not the right.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Those are just reflex arcs; he’s under anesthesia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or he’s lost sensation in some places.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Or the hypoxia from the arrest stunned his CNS.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Only one way to tell. Do some ATA sensory evoked potentials.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We can’t do that while he’s in a coma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Only two ways to tell. Get a hammer and check his deep tendon reflexes.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Won’t work. He needs muscle relaxants to be on the ventilator.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Only one more way to tell. Pupillary reflexes.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: All that tests is the brainstem.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See, I was right; only one way to tell. Do some ATA sensory evoked potentials.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I just said we can’t do that while he’s in a coma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So wake him up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t go towards the light. You’ll fall and break your hip.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: What’s happening? I --

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You took a little nap.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: No, I… I told you I didn’t want --

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry, little deaf in one ear. Your bone marrow was hypocellular; we ruled out lupus and pulmonary fibrosis, but it looks like it could be attacking your nerves.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: So, this is all a waste, a huge fail… failure. Impossible, you’re Gregory House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We need to attach some sensors to your skin.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look, we can’t do what you want; we’ve assigned a nurse to watch you so you can’t do it either. So, you might as well just let us do the test.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: No. I wanna be discharged.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You can’t be discharged; you’ve got two chest tubes in.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: Then take them out!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, get over yourself. The ventilator puffed up your lungs; you’ll be fine for a few hours. Just let us run the tests.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ok. But first, let’s clean you up a little. That feel nice?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What are you trying to prove?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just cleaning him up. What’s it look like? Pay no attention to the man behind the curtain. House runs his thumb down Ezra’s right foot, and there is no reaction. He does the same to his left, and this time the foot twitches.]

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: Get out!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, I’m going already. Can’t you see I’m a cripple?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ok, so you got me curious.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was right; whatever is attacking his lungs is attacking his nerves.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You got that by splashing ice water on him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No sensation in the left leg, abdomen, right arm. Technology’s overrated.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That means the clean MRI of his brain means it’s just affecting the peripheral nerves.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And bone marrow.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Kawasaki’s would explain the kidney failure.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or lymphoma.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Or sarcoidosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: All potentially treatable. Question is which. We need to catch the little bastards in the act. What’s the largest organ?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Skin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We need to get a piece.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sure, we’ll just wait until he leaves his room without his skin, sneak in, and take a piece.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want you to get a skin sample for a biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And I wanna get a foot massage from Johnny Damon.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kawasaki’s disease, lymphoma, and sarcoidosis are all treatable.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And it could be a hundred other things that aren’t treatable. You have no idea.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But you do; you know everything.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I didn’t say that I -

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exactly! You can’t decide if we’re helping or hurting him; if he’s good or bad; or if you want paper, plastic, or a burlap sack. Do your damn job.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m not gonna lie to him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine, tell the truth. Just get me a pound of flesh.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: What do you want?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House wants to biopsy your skin; he sent me to get it.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: Oh. And you agreed.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I had nothing to do with putting you in a coma or any of the subsequent tests.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: Which brings us to now.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I read some of your articles.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: There were a lot of them.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: 1967 Massachusetts Medical Journal. You radiated babies. Just like that. No forms, no questions, nothing. Who knows how many cancers you caused.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: I don’t know. What I do know is we discovered techniques that prevent fatal kidney failures in hundreds of thousands of other kids.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re not sorry.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: I don’t regret what I did. Informed consent, patient rights - holds back research. What the hell are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Informed consent is holding back our diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: Good for you. Finally standing up for something; acting on what you believe.

utterance.speaker: Ali
utterance.content: Dr. House? Hi, how are you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not as good as you think I am.

utterance.speaker: Ali
utterance.content: Don’t worry, I’m not stalking you. My dad just lost his medicine; he had to come back for another prescription.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, right. He’s moving it on the street, isn’t he?

utterance.speaker: Ali
utterance.content: Yeah, my dad, the meth kingpin.

utterance.speaker: Ali
utterance.content: Why haven’t you returned any of my calls?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I plan to. In a couple of years.

utterance.speaker: Ali
utterance.content: I was just calling to say ‘thank you.’ And to tell you how impressed I was; you diagnosed my dad by just looking at him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Felt his glands, too.

utterance.speaker: Ali
utterance.content: Oh, there’s my dad; I gotta go.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. Me too.

utterance.speaker: Ali
utterance.content: Oh, and, you really don’t have to wait a couple of years to return my calls. Just six months; till I turn 18.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s not Kawasaki’s, either. What’s next?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Congo red.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Amyloidosis?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What the hell else would I mean by ‘Congo red?’

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s not on the list.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There’s no reason for it to be on the list.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: An abnormal protein is building up inside the cells of his body; shutting down his organs one by one. Explains everything; the infiltrates on the x-ray, the bone marrow, kidney failure.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We rejected amyloidosis, because it didn’t fit the first symptom we found. It would affect his heart.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It did.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It wasn’t on the stress test.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We didn’t push him hard enough. Add the stain; let’s find out.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Congo red added.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Change the polarization of the light, already.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That means it should be treatable.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How the hell you pull that out of --

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not outta mine. I had a muse.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Oh, God. Protein type AA.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: Dr. House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have amyloidosis; it’s in your lungs, kidneys, bone marrow, and brain.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: Why should I believe you now?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I was lying, I wouldn’t tell you the subtype is AA. It’s terminal.

utterance.speaker: Ezra
utterance.content: Congratulations, you got your answer.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Ezra Powell passed away last night. I’m sure you already knew about that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. I just got in.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The nurse charted at 2 AM; he was stable. Breathing labored, but regular. And at 2:30 he suddenly stopped. You know anything about that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I did, would you really wanna know?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m proud of you.
